definition:
A subset $A$ of a topological space is said to be *dense-in-itself* if
$A$ contains no isolated points.

Note that if the subset $A$ is also a closed set, then $A$ will be a
perfect set. Conversely, every perfect set is dense-in-itself.

A simple example of a set which is dense-in-itself but not closed (and
hence not a perfect set) is the subset of irrational numbers. This set
is dense-in-itself because every neighborhood of an irrational number
$x$ contains at least one other irrational number $y \ne x$. On the
other hand, this set of irrationals is not closed because every rational
number lies in its closure.

For similar reasons, the set of rational numbers is also dense-in-itself
but not closed.
